questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

 

Montgomery T tube is a type of silicone stent used in the management of tracheal and subglottic stenosis. It is T-shaped to allow it to fit snugly in the trachea with one limb exiting the stoma, allowing for breathing through the upper airway or the tube itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a device inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to facilitate speech in patients who have had a total laryngectomy

 

Option C. Blom-Singer prosthesis is a type of tracheoesophageal puncture voice prosthesis used for voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy. When a patient has their larynx removed, typically due to cancer, they lose their natural voice. A Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way valve inserted between the trachea and the esophagus that allows air to be diverted into the esophagus to produce sound, enabling the patient to speak. It is placed during surgery or as an office procedure after the surgical site has healed.

 

Option D. A Grommet, also known as a tympanostomy tube or ventilation tube, is a small tube inserted into the eardrum to allow air to enter the middle ear. It is used to treat recurrent middle ear infections (acute otitis media) or to relieve chronic fluid accumulation in the middle ear (otitis media with effusion). Grommets help reduce the frequency of ear infections and improve hearing by allowing the continuous drainage of fluid and equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the external atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: Angular stomatitis and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

 

Explanation: 

 

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is most characteristically associated with angular stomatitis, also known as cheilosis, which is inflammation of the corners of the mouth. Additionally, riboflavin deficiency can lead to atrophic glossitis, also referred to as geographic tongue. These oral manifestations are the hallmark signs of riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency results in pellagra, which is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis (especially around the Casal's necklace), dementia, and death if left untreated. While pellagra can have significant consequences, it is not primarily associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option C. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause beriberi in populations consuming polished rice and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics. Beriberi affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems, while Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by neurological symptoms. However, thiamine deficiency is not directly linked to angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is common in strict vegetarians and can lead to peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord as a severe complication. Pernicious anemia may also occur as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. While these conditions are serious, they are not specifically associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Angular stomatitis (cheilosis) and atrophic glossitis (geographic tongue) are the most characteristic oral manifestations of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs cause visual problems as an adverse effect? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug that can cause visual problems as an adverse effect. It is known for its potential to lead to optic neuritis, which can result in changes in visual acuity and color vision. Monitoring of vision is important during the use of ethambutol, and if visual disturbances occur, the drug may need to be discontinued to prevent further optic nerve damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is not typically associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is not known to cause visual problems. However, it is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy as potential adverse effects.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is not commonly associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug known for its association with visual problems. It can cause optic neuritis and changes in color vision, which may be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Type I Cryoglobulinemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins (usually IgM or IgG) that precipitate in cold temperatures. Type I cryoglobulinemia features include monoclonal Ig (usually IgM), hyperviscosity, thrombosis, and normal complement levels. Unlike Types II and III (mixed cryoglobulinemias), Type I cryoglobulinemia is not associated with rheumatoid factor activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperviscosity: This is incorrect as an answer because hyperviscosity is a key feature of Type I cryoglobulinemia. The monoclonal paraproteins in Type I can lead to symptoms of hyperviscosity, including visual disturbances, headaches, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Monoclonal IgM paraprotein: This is incorrect as an answer because monoclonal immunoglobulins, particularly IgM, are the defining characteristic of Type I cryoglobulinemia, typically associated with plasma cell dyscrasias.

 

Option C. Normal complement levels: This is incorrect as an answer because Type I cryoglobulinemia is indeed associated with normal C3/C4 complement levels, unlike the hypocomplementemia seen in Type II mixed cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by monoclonal immunoglobulins, hyperviscosity, and normal complement levels, but lacks the rheumatoid factor activity that is characteristic of mixed cryoglobulinemias (Types II and III).

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

 

The patient likely received intravenous metoclopramide, a common anti-emetic, which can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as dystonia. Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, leading to repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This condition can be painful and distressing.

 

The treatment of choice for drug-induced dystonia is an anticholinergic medication. Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug that can effectively relieve dystonic reactions by blocking acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, thereby restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is primarily used to treat motion sickness and postoperative nausea. It is not effective for treating dystonia induced by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option C. Levodopa: Levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. It is not appropriate for treating acute dystonic reactions caused by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option D. Cyproheptadine: Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic and anticholinergic properties. While it can be used for some dystonic reactions, it is not the first-line treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Explanation:


Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: Phenomenon of renal colic, swelling in the loin which disappears after passing urine is called? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dietl's crisis

 

Explanation:

 

Dietl's crisis refers to a clinical triad of renal colic (severe flank pain), intermittent loin swelling, and relief of symptoms with passage of a large volume of urine. This occurs in cases of intermittent hydronephrosis, particularly with pelvi-ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction. 

 

The swelling represents the distended renal pelvis that becomes temporarily obstructed, causing pain, and then relieves when the obstruction clears, allowing passage of the accumulated urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Murphy's triad - This refers to right lower quadrant pain, vomiting, and fever, which are characteristic of acute appendicitis.

 

Option B. Saint's triad - This is the association of diverticular disease, gallstones, and hiatal hernia, completely unrelated to urinary symptoms.

 

Option D. Charcot's triad - This includes right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever, associated with ascending cholangitis due to biliary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dietl's crisis represents intermittent hydronephrosis with the characteristic triad of loin pain, swelling, and relief after passing large volumes of urine, typically seen in patients with PUJ obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

The given clinical scene and image shows a post-op tracheal stump created for breathing in patients of total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

 

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

 

Complications after total laryngectomy:

 

  • Permanent tracheostomy: upper end of trachea is directly sutured to skin for the patient to breathe.
  • Speech difficulties: To help patient speak after removal of larynx, there are various techniques.

 

1. Oesophageal speech:  patient is taught to swallow air and release which vibrates pharyngo-oesophageal segment and produces a very low sound.

 

2. Tracheo-oesophageal speech: most effective, artificial prostheses like Blom-singer valve / Provox / Groningen are inserted.

 

3. Electrolarynx: electrical device held on the skin of the neck vibrates and produce voice.

 

  • Loss of smell and decreased taste sensation
  • Swallowing difficulty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.

 

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Involves creating a larger incision in the neck to access the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

choices.text: Lunate at place while others dislocate
Lunate is displaced while other are at place
Lunate is displaced volarly while carpus dislocate dorsally

questions.text: Perilunate dislocation is defined as:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lunate at place while others dislocate

 

WRIST DISLOCATION

 

 

A. Normal; B. Lunate dislocation; C. Perilunate dislocation; D. Normal

 

1. Lunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate dislocates anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position

 

 

A. Pie sign; B. Spilled tea pot sign

 

2. Perilunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally.
  • Perilunate dislocation is more common
  • Most common type: Trans-scaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation
  • Complications: AVN, osteoarthritis and median nerve injury
  • Median nerve is most commonly injured nerve
  • The most commonly used method for closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Lunate is displaced while other are at place. This occurs in lunate dislocation.

 

Option C. Capitate dislocates volarly. This is rarely seen. There is dislocation of distal end of capitate at the capitate-metacarpal joint. It involves disruption of the joint and the intercarpal ligaments of the distal carpal row and minimally displaced fracture of trapezoid. This type of injury can be missed during the evaluation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Perilunate dislocation is defined as the dislocation of all carpal bones except for the lunate, which remains at its place.

questions.text: A student consumed fried rice and presented shortly after with nausea and vomiting. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacillus cereus

 

The key clinical presentation here is the rapid onset of symptoms ("shortly after") following consumption of fried rice. Bacillus cereus causes two types of food poisoning: an emetic (vomiting) type and a diarrheal type. The emetic type, which is what we see in this case, has a very short incubation period of 1-4 hours and is commonly associated with consumption of fried rice. The bacteria produce a heat-stable toxin called cereulide that causes the rapid onset of nausea and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli typically causes symptoms after 24-72 hours and is more commonly associated with undercooked meat or contaminated water

 

Option C. Neisseria species: Neisseria species are not typically food-borne pathogens and are instead associated with meningitis and gonorrhea

 

Option D. Clostridium species: Clostridium species (like C. perfringens) typically have longer incubation periods (8-16 hours) and cause primarily diarrheal illness

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Bacillus cereus food poisoning presenting with rapid onset nausea and vomiting (1-4 hours) after consuming fried rice is a classic presentation that must be recognized for proper diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: A patient presents with the skin lesion shown below. What can be used for treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The image depicts a patient with a "Casal's necklace" rash, a characteristic sign of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.

 

Pellagra is referred to as the "4D disease": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia, and Death. The treatment of choice for pellagra is nicotinamide, also known as vitamin B3 or niacin, which addresses the niacin deficiency underlying the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): While important for various bodily functions, it's not the specific treatment for pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Primarily involved in vision and immune function, not relevant to pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Crucial for wound healing and immune response, but doesn't address niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace, a dermatological manifestation with a symmetrical rash resembling a necklace around the neck, is a hallmark sign of pellagra, a condition resulting from niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. The primary treatment for pellagra involves niacin supplementation.

questions.text: A newborn baby is born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder Exstrophy  


The correct diagnosis is Bladder Exstrophy, a congenital condition where the bladder is turned inside out and exposed outside the body. It typically presents with an open, red mass in the lower abdominal area, often just below the umbilical cord, which is consistent with the image provided. This condition occurs due to a failure in the development of the abdominal wall and urogenital structures, leading to the bladder being exposed outside the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines, liver, and other organs protrude outside of the abdomen through the umbilical ring but are covered by a thin membrane or sac. The characteristic feature is that the protruding organs are enclosed in a sac, unlike in bladder exstrophy, where no covering sac is present.

 

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is another abdominal wall defect where the intestines protrude outside of the body but without any covering membrane, typically located to the right of the umbilical cord. However, it does not involve the bladder and appears distinctly different as only intestines are seen without any protective sac.

 

 

Option D. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital condition resulting from an incomplete obliteration of the vitellointestinal duct. It is a small pouch on the wall of the lower part of the small intestine and does not involve external defects or protrusions visible on the abdominal surface. It usually presents with painless rectal bleeding or obstruction.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Bladder Exstrophy is characterized by the bladder being exposed outside the body, appearing as a red mass in the lower abdomen with no covering membrane. It differs from other abdominal wall defects like omphalocele and gastroschisis, which involve the protrusion of abdominal contents with or without a protective sac.

questions.text: An adult male presented to the OPD with a swelling in the scrotum which was painful. The patient was having fever as well. The swelling was in relation to the tunica vaginalis and fluid collection was present. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocele

 

The patient presents with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is noted to be in relation to the tunica vaginalis with fluid collection, which points towards a secondary hydrocele due to an underlying condition.

 

The combination of painful scrotal swelling and fever is indicative of an inflammatory or infectious process, most commonly acute epididymo-orchitis. This condition is inflammation of the epididymis and testicle, often caused by bacterial infection. The presence of fluid around the testicle, known as a hydrocele, is a secondary response to the inflammation.

 

A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. Secondary hydroceles can develop in response to infections, injuries, or inflammatory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicocele: This is an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum (the pampiniform plexus). It is typically not associated with fever or acute pain and does not involve fluid collection related to the tunica vaginalis.

 

Option C. Cystocele: This condition involves the bladder bulging into the vaginal space and is unrelated to scrotal swelling.

 

Option D. Torsion testis: Testicular torsion involves the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to severe pain and swelling. While torsion can occur in adults, it is more common in adolescents. It usually does not present with fever unless secondary infection occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful scrotal swelling with fever and fluid collection in an adult male, particularly in relation to the tunica vaginalis, suggests a diagnosis of secondary hydrocele due to epididymo-orchitis.

questions.text: A woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

During the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism. This preference is due to the fact that PTU has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole, which is associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis (a congenital skin defect). PTU is considered safer in early pregnancy, especially during organogenesis (the first trimester), as it crosses the placenta less readily than Methimazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Methimazole is typically avoided during the first trimester because it is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly the risk of aplasia cutis and other congenital abnormalities.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is a prodrug that is converted to Methimazole in the body. Like Methimazole, it is also avoided during the first trimester due to the risk of congenital defects.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy at any stage, as it can destroy fetal thyroid tissue, leading to permanent hypothyroidism in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism due to its lower risk of causing birth defects compared to other antithyroid medications.

questions.text:
Arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings:(NEET PG 2021)

  • pH: 7.52
  • HCO3: 30 mEq/L
  • PaCO2: 45 mmHg
  • Na: 123 mEq/L
  • K: 3.2 mEq/L
  • Cl: 67 mEq/L

What is the cause of her ABG findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Persistent vomiting

 

The ABG report indicates the patient has metabolic alkalosis, as evidenced by the elevated pH (7.52) and increased bicarbonate (HCO3) level (30 mEq/L). The slight increase in PaCO2 (45 mmHg) is a compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis, as the body attempts to retain CO2 to balance the pH.

 

Persistent vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (HCl), which results in metabolic alkalosis. The electrolyte disturbances seen here (hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and hyponatremia) are typical of persistent vomiting. Vomiting causes a loss of hydrogen ions (leading to increased bicarbonate), chloride (hypochloremia), and potassium (hypokalemia), along with fluid loss, which can dilute serum sodium levels, leading to hyponatremia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically presents with metabolic acidosis (low pH and low HCO3) rather than metabolic alkalosis. Additionally, DKA is usually associated with hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Septic shock: Septic shock usually causes metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis from poor tissue perfusion. It does not typically present with metabolic alkalosis and the specific electrolyte disturbances seen here.

 

Option D. Renal tubular acidosis: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is characterized by a defect in the kidneys' ability to acidify the urine, leading to metabolic acidosis. The ABG findings in RTA would show a low pH and low bicarbonate levels, which is opposite to what is observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent vomiting can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia. This is due to the loss of gastric acid and electrolytes, and the characteristic ABG findings include elevated pH and bicarbonate levels. Treatment often involves fluid and electrolyte replacement, particularly with normal saline to correct chloride levels.

questions.text: Rukmani is attending a Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme. How frequently is it conducted? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Every month

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee organizes a Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day once every month.

 

Rukmani is attending a "Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme," which is likely referring to the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day organized by the committee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Programme, which Rukmani is attending, is conducted once every month by the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee.

questions.text: Ga-68 PSMA scan is useful for the diagnosis of which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostate cancer

 

Ga-68 PSMA (Gallium-68 Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen) PET scan is a nuclear medicine imaging technique primarily used for detecting prostate cancer. PSMA is a protein expressed on the surface of prostate cancer cells, and the Ga-68 radiotracer binds specifically to this antigen, allowing for precise imaging of prostate cancer lesions. This scan is particularly useful in staging and detecting the spread of prostate cancer, making it a key tool in the management of the disease.

 

Note –

 

Gallium 68 Dotanoc – IOC for Neuroendocrine Tumor. This diagnostic test is particularly effective because it targets somatostatin receptors, which are commonly present on these tumors. While it is especially useful for identifying neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas, Gallium 68 Dotanoc can be applied to locate other types of NETs throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver cancer: Liver cancer imaging is usually done using other modalities such as CT, MRI, or PET scans with different tracers.

 

Option C. Lung cancer: Lung cancer is usually diagnosed and staged with other imaging techniques, such as CT scans, PET scans using FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), or biopsy.

 

Option D. Colon cancer: Colon cancer diagnosis and staging rely on colonoscopy, CT scans, and sometimes FDG PET scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ga-68 PSMA scan is specifically designed for the diagnosis and management of prostate cancer, as it targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen expressed on prostate cancer cells.

choices.text: Anterior transmural
Posterior transmural

questions.text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior transmural

 

As a post-MI complication, anterior transmural infarcts contribute to aneurysm formation.

 

Myocardial infarction (MI) complications such left ventricular aneurysms (LVAs) and pseudoaneurysms can cause mortality or severe morbidity. The most frequent outcome of MI is an LVA, which typically involves the anterior wall.

 

Conduction blockages, right ventricular involvement, or both are more likely to make posterior transmural infarcts problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendocardial: These infarcts affect only the innermost layers of the heart wall and do not typically cause aneurysms.

 

Option C. Posterior transmural: While serious and affecting the full thickness of the heart wall, posterior infarcts are less likely than anterior infarcts to result in aneurysm formation due to the smaller area typically involved and differing hemodynamic forces.

 

Option D. Inferior wall: Inferior MIs can lead to complications like arrhythmias or heart block but are less commonly associated with aneurysm formation compared to anterior transmural MIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior transmural myocardial infarctions are most commonly associated with the formation of left ventricular aneurysms due to the location, extent of myocardial damage, and the dynamics of ventricular pressure that exacerbate the risk of wall outpouching and aneurysm development in this region.
